2-3.label: 2–3 years
development_focus: Developing basic independence through simple choices
Early language exposure through repetition and naming
Gross motor exploration and body awareness
Sensory exploration using hands and movement
constraints: Activities must be very short and flexible
Instructions should be limited to one simple step at a time
Avoid all small objects that could pose choking hazards
Teacher must closely supervise all materials and interactions
Focus on process rather than outcome
No abstract concepts; learning should be concrete and experiential
pedagogical_notes: Learning happens primarily through sensory experience and movement
Parallel play is developmentally appropriate; cooperation is not expected
Repetition is essential and should be encouraged
Activities should allow children to enter and exit freely

3-4.label: 3–4 years
development_focus: Developing fine motor control through hands-on activities
Building emotional awareness and basic self-regulation
constraints: Instructions should be limited to 2–3 clear steps
Activities should include opportunities for movement and rest
Materials must be safe, durable, and familiar
Tasks should allow multiple correct outcomes
Adult guidance should support, not dominate, the activity
pedagogical_notes: Play-based learning is the primary mode of engagement
Children benefit from verbalizing actions and observations
Mistakes are part of learning and should not be corrected harshly
Activities should balance structure with freedom

5-6.label: 5–6 years
development_focus: Developing early logical thinking and problem-solving skills
Improving social collaboration and role-based play
Using language to explain ideas and reflect on outcomes
Increasing independence and responsibility within group activities
constraints: Activities should include a clear goal but allow different solutions
Instructions can include up to 3–4 steps
Challenges should be achievable but slightly demanding
Encourage peer collaboration without forcing it
pedagogical_notes: Children are capable of reflecting on what worked and what did not
Problem-solving should be encouraged through open-ended questions
Activities can introduce simple rules and constraints
The teacher acts as a facilitator rather than a director
